title: 107_s1868
content:
The Act is titled the "National Child Protection and Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to define a "qualified State program" as policies and procedures in place to implement the Act, including requirements for timely national criminal history background checks, limited fees for State background checks, designated authorized agencies, and qualified entities submitting background check requests. The term 'routinely' in the National Child Protection Act of 1993 refers to instances where a high percentage of nationwide background check requests are returned to qualified entities within specific timeframes. SEC. 3. STRENGTHENING AND ENFORCING THE NATIONAL CHILD PROTECTION ACT AND THE VOLUNTEERS FOR CHILDREN ACT. Section 3 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for providers caring for children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to include guidelines for state programs and qualifications for providers caring for vulnerable populations. The Attorney General must respond to state inquiries within 15 business days. The Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002 allows qualified entities in states without programs to request national criminal background checks from the Attorney General to assess providers' suitability for caring for children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. The Attorney General must respond to requests within 20 business days. The Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002 allows qualified entities to request national criminal background checks from the Attorney General for assessing providers' suitability for caregiving. This can be done directly through a State authorized agency, and the process must be completed within 20 business days. SEC. 4. DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION.

The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow the Attorney General and State agencies to share criminal history background check records with qualified entities. 

SEC. 7. OFFICE FOR VOLUNTEER AND PROVIDER SCREENING.

The Attorney General will establish an Office for Volunteer and Provider Screening to facilitate national criminal background checks for care providers. Model guidelines will be provided to assist qualified entities in making fitness determinations.

SEC. 5. FEES. SEC. 5. FEES.

Amends the National Child Protection Act of 1993 regarding fees for national criminal fingerprint background checks. Limits fees to $5 for volunteers and $18 for providers with qualified entities. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology, providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. Additional funds will be given to hire personnel to train county law enforcement agencies on inputting criminal data into the national background check system. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology, providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. States with a qualified program can receive up to $2,000,000 in funding. Appropriations are authorized to improve fingerprint technology units and hire data entry personnel in each State and the District of Columbia for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. SEC. 7. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Information from national criminal fingerprint background checks cannot be altered except for national security reasons. Qualified entities must designate a representative to handle requested information and delete unnecessary details. Releasing this information to unauthorized individuals carries criminal penalties. The qualified entity's organizational leadership may face a $50,000 fine or up to 1 year in prison for each violation. SEC. 8 of the Act authorizes appropriations of $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Funds appropriated under this section remain available until expended.
